Fig. 1 (a) Methane conversion, (b) benzene yield, (c) naphthalene yield, and (d) C2 yield over time for the MDA reaction and O-MDA reaction over Mo/H-ZSM-5 catalyst. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 (a) Methane conversion and (b) benzene yield in O-MDA reaction over Mo/H-ZSM-5 catalyst with different O2-regeneration temperature. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Changes of (a) methane conversion rate, (b) aromatization formation rate, (c) hydrogen formation rate and (d) CO formation rate with TOS during O-MDA reaction-regeneration process. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 (a) The relationship between methane consumption rate and TOS and (b) the methane initial consumption rate as a function of reaction time in different reaction regeneration cycles. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 (a) Product selectivity, (b)changes of C2H4 formation rate with methane conversion rate and (c) changes of C6H6 formation rate with methane conversion rate in O-MDA reaction regeneration cycles and (d) the amount of accumulated C6H6 formation rate with time on stream in MDA, O-MDA and O-MDA reaction regeneration processes. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 XRD patterns of HZSM-5 and oxide Mo/HZSM-5 catalysts at (a) 2θ = 5–55°, (b) 2θ = 25–30° and (C) relative XRD peak intensities at 2θ = 7.8° and 22.9° for the HZSM − 5 and oxide Mo/HZSM − 5 catalysts. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 (a) N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and (b) pore size distribution of oxide Mo/HZSM-5 catalysts. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Raman spectra of HZSM-5 and Mo/HZSM-5 catalysts (a) before and (b) after O-MDA reaction. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 (a) TG, (b) DTG and (c) deconvolution of DTG profiles of the used Mo/HZSM-5 catalysts. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 27Al MAS NMR spectra of the fresh Mo/HZSM-5（O-1）catalyst and regenerated Mo/HZSM-5（O-8）catalyst. Reaction regeneration cycle of methane dehydroaromatization (MDA) with oxygen-containing gas components was studied. XRD, BET, Raman, NH3-TPD, O2-TG/DTG, TEM and 27Al-NMR were used to monitor textural structure, Mo species, and acid sites of catalyst before and after regeneration. Addition of oxygen components can extend reaction time per pass but cannot prevent the deactivation of regenerated catalyst. MoO3 species, acidity, and texture properties of Mo/HZSM-5 was identical after first regeneration, which may account for complete recovery of methane conversion and aromatic formation. During regeneration, the inevitable increase in Mo species size disrupts carbon deposition and significantly reduces methane dissociation. The crystallinity and number of strong acid sites of Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst decreased to a stable level before the collapse of zeolite framework without hindering aromatic formation. The recovered large-sized Mo species may accelerate the collapse of zeolite framework, irreversibly destroying Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Methane dehydroaromatization Mo/H-ZSM-5 catalyst Reaction regeneration Deactivation Oxygen-containing components Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Natural gas, as a clean and abundant fossil fuel, is considered as a promising alternative to oil [1,2]. However, the chemical inertness of C-H bond in methane molecule, the main component of natural gas, makes it difficult to be converted [1–3]. Currently, the industrial conversion process of natural gas usually employs steam reforming to convert methane to syngas, followed by Fischer-Tropsch synthesis to obtain useful chemicals such as methanol and liquid fuels [1,4]. However, the high capital cost makes this approach economically attractive only on a very large scale [1,4,5]. Direct conversion of methane to higher hydrocarbons is considered the most cost-effective process for natural gas utilization. The methods of direct conversion of methane can be divided into oxidation and non-oxidation [2,3]. Among them, methane dehydroaromatization (MDA) is one of the most promising reactions for obtaining high value-added products from natural gas [3–6]. The main reaction of MDA process is: 6CH4 =C6H6 + 9 H2 and the primarily products of MDA are liquid aromatic hydrocarbons and hydrogen. The process not only produces pure hydrogen (H2) for fuel cells, but also produces hydrocarbon chemicals that do not emit carbon dioxide, making it extremely valuable in the field of C1 chemistry, methane and natural gas conversion, clean energy utilization, hydrogen utilization, carbon emissions peak and carbon neutralization [3–6]. Catalyst deactivation at high reaction temperatures required for methane activation is a major bottleneck for MDA industrialization, mainly due to the accumulation of carbonaceous deposits on Mo/zeolite catalysts [7–10]. Various approaches have been tried to reduce the coke deposition and extend the life of MDA catalyst. Modifying the acidic property of zeolite support can achieve good interaction between metal and acid sites and improve the catalytic performance [3,4,6]. Increasing reaction pressure can delay coke deposition and improve the cumulative yield of hydrocarbon products [11]. The continuous co-feeding of oxidants (O2, CO2, CO, H2O) in methane stream stabilizes the active Mo species of Mo/zeolite and slows down MDA reaction deactivation [12–15]. Coupling reaction of OCM, methane steam reforming, methane CO2 reforming, methane CO2 autothermal reforming (MCAR) with MDA reaction can delay the accumulation of coke on Brӧnsted acid of zeolite and extend the life of the catalyst [16–18]. Co-feeding of H2 and methane is an effective method to suppress coke formation, but methane conversion is inhibited due to thermodynamic equilibrium limitations [1,3,19]. Periodic alternation of methane and regeneration hydrogen reduces coke deposition on molybdenum/zeolite catalyst during the reaction, resulting in high and stable catalyst performance [19,20]. Shu et al. investigated the performance of Mo/HZSM-5 in MDA process using 30–30 min switching between CH4 and H2 [21]. Sun et al. achieved a stable MDA performance of 5.5%Mo/ZSM-5 catalysts for over 1000 h [20]. In order to industrialize the MDA reaction, Zhang and co-workers have done much work to optimize this operation mode for selecting reactor type, optimizing reaction conditions and improving the practicality of Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst [22–24]. This CH4-H2 conversion strategy is currently the most industrially promising strategy, but its drawbacks include the use of excess hydrogen and long periods of non-optimal yields to produce aromatic hydrocarbon products [6,20]. Regeneration of the coked Mo/zeolite catalyst with O2 should be another effective way to achieve long-term operation of MDA reaction. The pain point of this strategy is how to overcome the damage of Mo species to the framework Al during catalyst regeneration to form aluminum molybdate [25,26]. Bai found that in-situ regeneration of Mo/MCM-22 catalyst with 1%O2 at reaction temperature can restore the activity of MDA reaction after 1–2 regeneration cycles [27]. Portilla found that the use of a short reaction time (1.5 h) and sufficient regeneration time (0.5 h) in a continuous regeneration cycle mode extended the life of the Mo/zeolite catalyst and improved the aromatics yield in MDA reaction [28]. Kosinov found that periodic pulsing of oxygen into the methane feed results in substantially higher cumulative product yield with synthesis gas at a H2/CO ratio close to two [26]. Han's study showed that low-temperature regeneration of O2 at 450 °C can promote the dispersion of Mo2C and significantly prolong the catalyst life of MDA [29]. MDA reaction with low aromatics yield was not conducive to the accumulation of aromatics in the long-term reaction regeneration process. Our previous study showed that the addition of oxygen-containing components to the methane feed via MCAR/MDA reaction coupling can effectively eliminate carbon deposition, allowing MDA reaction to maintain 60–80% aromatics selectivity and desirable benzene yield for a longer period of time [18]. The aim of this study to extend the effective reaction time in an MDA reaction-regeneration process by co-adding oxygen-containing components in methane feed. XRD, BET, Raman, NH3-TPD, O2-TG/DTG and 27Al-NMR were used to monitor the changes of micropore structure, Mo species and acid sites of Mo/zeolite catalyst before and after regeneration. MDA reaction performance was evaluated on Mo/H-ZSM-5 catalyst to determine reproducibility differences in reaction regeneration steps. The deactivation mechanism of Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst is discussed by correlating MDA reaction performance with catalyst characterization in different reaction regeneration steps, which may help to design more efficient catalysts in MDA reaction regeneration process. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Preparation of the Mo/H-ZSM-5 catalysts HZSM−5 (SiAl = 25) zeolite was provided by the catalyst factory of Nankai University (Tianjin, China). Ammonium heptamolybdate ((NH4)6Mo7 2O4.4H2O) was supplied by Gresia Chemical Technology Co., Ltd. (Chengdu, China) and used as a Mo precursor. A 6 wt% Mo/HZSM−5 catalyst was prepared by incipient wetness impregnation method using an aqueous solution containing a given amount of ammonium heptamolybdate. After impregnation, the sample was dried at room temperature overnight and at 393 k for 6 h. The sample after calcination at 773 K for 4 h was named Mo/HZSM−5 catalyst. 2.2 Characterization Adsorption and desorption isotherms of nitrogen was measured in a static measurement mode on a Quantachrome IQ (USA) instrument. The specific surface area (SBET) was calculated using the multi-point Brunauer-Emmett-Taylor (BET) formula. The micropore area (Smicro) and the micropore volume (Vmicro) were calculated using a t-plot curve. Pore size distributions of micropores were calculated using a Horvath-Kawazoe (HK) method. The crystalline structures of the catalysts were determined by X-ray diffraction (XRD) using an Bruker D8 advance power diffraction system using Cu Ka radiation (λ = 0.15406 nm), operated at 40 kV and 30 mA. The Raman spectrum of the catalyst was recorded on a LabRAM HR Evolution instrument (JOBIN YVON, France) using an argon ion laser operating at a wavelength of 532 nm. The Gaussian methods were used to deconvolute the Raman spectra of the Mo species and carbonaceous materials on the surface of the Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst. NH3-TPD measurements were taken using a TP- 5000II adsorption apparatus (Xianquan, Tianjin). 100 mg sample was increased to 773 K at a heating rate of 10 K /min and kept at 773 K for 60 min, then cool the sample to not less than 393 K. After saturating with a 10 vol% NH3/N2 mixture gas at 393 K for 60 min, the sample was re-heated from 393 K to 873 K at a heating rate of 10 K /min and kept at 873 K for 30 min under N2 atmosphere. The desorbed NH3 was monitored by thermal conductivity detector (TCD) signals. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on a PerkinElmer TGA 4000 instrument with 2–3 mg of each sample in the temperature range of 303–1023 K at a heating rate of 10 K /min under a constant oxygen flow at 100 ml min-1. The amount of coke and its combustion heat were obtained from the total weight loss and integration of the heat flow. 27Al NMR spectra of the catalysts were measured on a Bruker AVANCE 400 NEO WB spectrometer at 200 MHz with the pulse duration of 2 μs and recycling delay of 5 s. TEM of oxide Mo/HZSM-5(O-1) and Mo/HZSM-5(O-5) catalyst was carried out on JEM-2100 F (Japanese Electronic Crops) at 200 keV. ICP analysis of the fresh and regenerated Mo/HZSM-5 was measured, and the Mo content of Mo/HZSM-5(O-1), Mo/HZSM-5(O-2), Mo/HZSM-5(O-3), Mo/HZSM-5(O-4) and Mo/HZSM-5(O-5) catalyst is 5.3 wt%, 5.7 wt%, 6.2 wt%, 6.7 wt% and 6.6 wt%, respectively. 2.3 Methane dehydroaromatization (MDA) evaluation 400 mg of 40–60 mesh Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst was placed in a tubular quartz reactor having an inner diameter of 0.8 mm. The catalyst was held in the constant temperature zone of the furnace while quartz wool was placed on both sides. Mass flow controllers were used to control the feed of individual gases. The reaction temperature was raised to 973 K at a rate of 10 K/min at a gas hourly space velocity of 1500 ml/(g.h) under a flow of 90% CH4/10% N2 by volume. After stabilization at 973 K for 10 min, the reaction temperature was re-increased to 1023 K at a rate of 5 K /min. And then, the reaction gas was introduced after stabilization at 1023 K in a methane atmosphere for 10 min. For MDA reaction, the reaction gas was a stream 90% CH4/10% N2. For O-MDA reaction with co-adding oxygen-containing components to methane feed, the reaction gas was a mixing steam of 90% CH4/10% N2 stream with 10% CO2/10% O2/80% Ar at a ratio of 2:1. The analytical calculation of the product is the same as that reported in the literature [16–18]. Effluent was analyzed by an online gas chromatograph equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) and a thermal conductor detector (TCD). The FID was used for the analysis of CH4, C6H6, C7H8, and C10H8, while the TCD was used for the analysis of H2, N2, O2, CH4, CO, CO2 C2H4, and C2H6. The CH4 conversion was calculated by using N2 as an internal standard in the feed. The diagram of O-MDA reaction regeneration cyclic protocol was shown in Scheme 1. Oxide Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst was heated from room temperature to 973 K at a heating rate of 10 K/min in a gas mixture flow of 90% CH4/10% N2 (by volume) and held at 973 K for 10 min. Then the catalyst temperature was raised to 1023 K at a heating rate of 5 K/min and kept at 1023 K for 10 mins to fully carbonize the catalyst. Thereafter, a stream of 10% CO2/10% O2/80% Ar (by volume) was co-fed with the methane stream to react for 6 h. After that, the used catalyst is cooled down in nitrogen flow to the room temperature. Regeneration of the used catalyst was carried out at 823 K for 120 min under Air stream (20 vol% in N2) with a gas flow of 10 ml/min to remove coke. Then the generated catalyst is cooled down in nitrogen flow to the room temperature. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 The choice of regeneration conditions for O-MDA reactions 3.1.1 The choice of effective reaction time for O-MDA reactions Fig. 1a-d compares the methane conversion, benzene yield, naphthalene yield, and C2 yield over time for the MDA reaction and O-MDA reaction over Mo/H-ZSM-5 catalyst. For MDA reaction, both methane conversion and benzene yield dropped rapidly in 900 min, while for O-MDA reaction, methane conversion and benzene yield declined relatively slowly from the initial stage of the reaction to 600 min, and then decreased rapidly. When O-MDA reaction was extended to 1200–1800 min, the methane conversion was constant at 4–5%, and benzene and aromatics were hardly detected. Consumed methane should be used for CO2 reforming of methane and autothermal reforming of methane. Similar to previous report, the addition of 10%CO2/10%O2/80%Ar to the methane stream can significantly extend catalyst life [18]. Studies have shown that the addition of gas-phase oxygen-containing components can convert the molybdenum structure to carbon oxides and slow down undesirable coking. Thus, intermediates of carbon oxides and carbides can be retained to prevent complete carburization of Mo species [13]. Compared with benzene, the yield of naphthalene decreased more rapidly. This phenomenon is attributed to the deactivation of the external Brӧnsted acid sites, as well as the reduction of the effective zeolite pore size due to coking [28,30]. Different from other products, C2 yield increased first and then decreased with time on stream (TOS). The appearance of the maximum C2 yield in the O-MDA reaction was significantly delayed. It is generally assumed that MDA reaction proceeds in a bifunctional mechanism. Methane dissociates on active Mo species to form CHx, which couples to form ethylene. Ethylene was oligomerized and aromatized to benzene and other aromatics at the acidic sites of the shape-selective zeolite [4,31]. As an intermediate, the yield of C2 depends on the conversion rate of methane to ethylene on active Mo species and the conversion rate of ethylene to benzene on Brӧnsted acid site. The ethylene yield reaches a maximum when the rate of benzene formation begins to decrease significantly. Coke deposited on Bronsted acid sites can be effectively removed when gas-phase oxygen-containing components are co-fed with methane, preventing the rapid deactivation of MDA reaction [18]. Thus, extending the time for ethylene to reach maximum yield. In this study, the effective reaction time for the subsequent O-MDA reaction regeneration cycle was chosen to be 6 h to maintain the desired benzene yield. 3.1.2 The choice of regeneration temperature for O-MDA reactions Fig. 2a-b compares the methane conversion and benzene yield in O-MDA reaction over Mo/H-ZSM-5 catalyst with different O2-regeneration temperature. Calcination in air at temperatures higher than 773 K is a considered as typical regeneration process [28,32]. It was found that coke can be completely removed by treating the deactivated catalyst with air for twenty minutes at 823 K [28,33,34]. This can also be confirmed by O2-TG characterization later in this study. As shown in Fig. 2a and b, high temperature calcination of deactivated catalysts is not conducive to the recovery of MDA activity. With low regeneration temperature, the benzene yield can be recovered to almost the same level as the fresh Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst. In this study, the regeneration temperature was chosen to be 823 K. O2-TG/DTG results indicated that all the coke deposition after O-MDA reaction could be completed burned off from the regenerated catalyst (Fig. S1). 3.2 Reaction performance of O-MDA in a reaction regeneration process Fig. 3a and b shows methane conversion rate and aromatization formation rate of O-MDA reaction regeneration cycle as a function of TOS. The processes between adjacent reaction regeneration cycles, including catalyst cooling, regeneration, and catalyst activation, were ignored. The methane conversion and aromatics yield of the catalyst were almost completely recovered after one regeneration cycle, which was consistent with the literature reports [27,28]. After Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst was regenerated for 5 times, the conversion rate of methane in O-MDA reaction tended to be stable, and the formation rate of aromatics continued to decrease. Fig. 3c shows the formation rate of H2 in O-MDA reaction regeneration cycle process as a function of TOS. Generally, hydrogen can be produced from the autothermal reforming（O2 +CO2）of methane and the conversion of methane to ethylene, ethane, benzene, and aromatics in MDA reaction. The absence of detectable CO2 and O2 in the product indicates the complete conversion of oxidized components. A good agreement was found between the H2 content detected in the effluent and the sum of H2 content from the generation of MDA products and CO formation through methane reacting with oxygenated components. Fig. 3d shows the formation rate of CO in O-MDA reaction regeneration cycle process as a function of TOS. CO yield was relatively stable throughout the O-MDA reaction regeneration cycle, fluctuating slightly in the range of 4–5%. According to previous reports, CO comes from the reaction of methane and O2 combustion, and the reaction of methane and CO2 through methane-CO2 reforming [17,18]. the oxygen-containing components can effectively eliminate carbon deposition on the surface of the catalyst during the O-MDA reaction and avoid rapid deactivation of the catalyst due to the accumulation polyaromatics (PAHs) with zeolite micropores [12,13]. Fig. 4a shows the methane consumption rate as a function of TOS for different reaction regeneration cycles. For MDA reaction, an induction period was found for converting oxide Mo species into more activated MoOxCy or MoCx species. During this period, more CH4 was consumed to carbonized MoOx species until the formation of benzene was gradually reached to a stable level [35]. When oxygen components were added into methane feed, the induction period time can be further prolonged. As shown in Fig. 4a, during the first 60 min of multiple reactions regeneration cycles, Mo/HZSM-5 catalysts also underwent an induction period with an increasing methane consumption. After the induction period, the slope of methane consumption rate with TOS in different reaction regeneration processes is nearly the same. Clearly, the significant reduction in methane conversion comes from the repeated regeneration process, rather than the reduction of active molybdenum species due to carbon deposition in O-MDA reaction. Therefore, the presence of oxygen-containing components in the methane feed can only delay the deactivation of Mo/HZSM-5 due to carbon deposition，but cannot prevent the decline of methane dissociation capacity during regeneration process. The deactivation mechanism of methane conversion in MDA reaction is significantly different from that in MDA reaction regeneration process. The decrease of methane dissociation capacity during the MDA reaction is due to the increase of graphitic carbon deposits on outer surface of Mo species [18,33,34]. According to the reference, a thin carbon layer was formed on the outer surface of Mo2C during the early stage of MDA reaction, covering the surface of active sites [10]. As the reaction proceeded, more Mo species were covered by carbon deposition. The decrease in the number of active Mo species directly leads to the decrease in methane dissociation capacity and methane conversion rate [8,10,36,37]. Apparently, this kind of deactivation can be recovered by combustion to remove carbon deposits. As suggested by ICP results (experimental section), the sublimation loss of Mo species in fresh and regenerated Mo/HZSM-5 catalysts are not significant even after MDA reactions at 1023 K and multiply regeneration at 823 K, despite oxygen-containing components was co-added with methane feed. Kosinov found that for pure MoO3, sublime occurs at a lower temperature of 973 K, whereas for MoO3 from aluminum molybdate, a higher temperature of 1073 K is required for sublimation to occur [32]. Han et. al. found that 5Mo/H-ZSM-5 underwent MoO3 sublimation and oxidative regeneration at 1123 K [29]. In Kosinov study, they attributed the persistence of molybdenum species in Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst after 823 K air calcination to the stabilization of molybdenum-oxo complexes on cation-exchange sites of the zeolite [26]. Generally, the oxidation of Mo-carbide to Mo-oxide is considered as the key to recovery the Mo species during reaction regeneration process [26]. It is speculated that reaction regeneration cycles, Mo species will undergo irreversible transformation, resulting in a rapid decline in the methane dissociation capacity. Although Portilla and Kosinov found that the sublimation loss of Mo species in MDA reaction was not significant, however, multiple reaction regeneration cycles will lead to the irreversible transformation of Mo species [26,28,32]. There are at least three ways that can lead to this irreversible transformation of the Mo species. Firstly，for a traditional MDA reaction, Mo species can combine with OH group of Brönsted acid to form Mo-oxo species, such as MoO2 2+ monomers, Mo2O5 2+ dimers and MoO2(OH)+ [3,6,38]. During the induction period of MDA reaction, Mo-oxo species were reduced and carbonized into MoOxCy and MoCx species, consisting of several Mo atoms dispersed within the pores of the zeolite [35]. Partially reduced monomeric and dimeric Mo species can be stabilized by zeolite framework [13,39]. Dispersed species can still remain in the pores as small (oxy) carbide particles, clusters, or even monatomic species during MDA reaction [6]. At longer reaction time, Mo-oxo species was fully carbonized and detached from zeolite and forming MoxCy clusters, predominantly on the outer zeolite surface and cause the deactivation of the catalyst [13,40,41]. Oxidation of larger Mo2C nanoparticles can only form agglomerated Mo species that are difficult to achieve highly redispersion. Hu found that oxidative regeneration at 823–1123 K induced (MoO4)2-(n) oligomerization and subsequent carburization of bulk Mo carbide cluster [29]. Secondly, in addition to highly dispersed Mo-oxo species within zeolite pores, some larger agglomerates were also found on external surface [3,6,8]. Kosinov found that stable Mo-oxo species were formed in zeolite channels when Mo loading was lower than 2 wt%, while Mo agglomeration on the outer surface of the catalyst was inevitable when Mo loading was high [42]. Portilla found that the MoO3-related H2 reduction peak of the Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst became sharper and shifted to higher temperatures after several regeneration cycles, while the Mo-oxo-related H2 reduction peak gradually disappeared, indicating the irreversible transformation of Mo-oxo into MoO3 crystals [28]. Hu found that the nano-MoO3-modified ZSM-5 had higher methane conversion and better resistance to carbonaceous deposits, and exhibited higher MDA reaction stability than the micro-MoO3-modified ZSM-5 [43]. Thirdly, isolated Mo species may induce the formation of aluminum molybdate formed by dealumination of zeolite framework [25,26,28,32]. Therefore, causing the irreversibly deactivation on MDA reaction. As shown in Fig. 4b, the initial methane consumption rate decreased significantly during the initial five regeneration cycles. From the fifth to eighth cycles, the initial consumption rate of methane decreased slightly. It has been hypothesized that the regeneration of the O-MDA reaction may involve three distinct deactivation stages. In the first stage, both methane conversion rate and the aromatics formation rate can be completely recovered. In the second stage, the conversion of methane decreased obviously while the yield of aromatics decreased with the decrease of methane conversion. In the third stage, the conversion of methane decreased slightly, but aromatics yield continues to decline. Fig. 5a shows the product selectivity as a function of TOS during O-MDA reaction-regeneration process. Product selectivity was obtained by normalizing the Carbon moles of ethylene, ethane, benzene, toluene, xylene, and naphthalene in the product. Unlike the continuous decrease in the initial methane consumption rate, the aromatics selectivity was relatively stable for the first five regeneration cycles. The initial aromatics selectivity can be almost completely restored after each reaction regeneration cycle. In each MDA reaction process, the benzene selectivity decreased continuously but in different ways. In the first two reaction regeneration processes, the decrease of aromatics selectivity was almost the same. During the second to fourth reaction regeneration cycles, the declining degree of aromatics selectivity gradually increases. From the fifth reaction regeneration cycles, the aromatics selectivity decreased to such an extent that C2 substituted benzene became the main product of the reaction even at the later stage of the reaction. The reason for the opposite C2 selectivity compared to the benzene selectivity is that, in the MDA reaction, benzene and aromatics are converted from ethylene or intermediate CxHy species at the Brönsted acid sites of zeolite HZSM-5 [3,6]. Therefore, as the benzene formation rate increases and decreases, the number of intermediate species decreases and increases, resulting in the opposite trends of C2 selectivity and benzene selectivity. Fig. 5b shows the formation rates of ethylene as a function of methane consumption rate in different O-MDA reaction regeneration process. The formation rate of ethylene is not related to methane consumption rate in the first MDA run. However, it was found that ethylene formation rate increased with decreasing methane consumption rate after the second reaction-regeneration cycles. Han found similar results in their study. They attribute this phenomenon to the fact that the deactivation of zeolite Brӧnsted acidic sites may precede the deactivation of the Mo2C sites [29]. When the deactivation of the acid center (covered by PAHs) is greater than the deactivation of the Mo2C species (covered by carbonaceous on Mo species), ethylene as an intermediate or the product from the CxHy species may be more likely to remain in MDA products. This phenomenon is more pronounced at low methane conversion rate when the Brӧnsted acid sites of Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst is seriously deactivated. Fig. 5c shows the formation rates of benzene as a function of methane consumption rate in different O-MDA reaction regeneration process, respectively. For a single pass O-MDA reaction, the formation rate of benzene continuously decreases with the decrease of methane consumption rate, and there is a good linear relationship between them, which is similar to that in Han's experiment [29]. The selectivity of benzene may vary throughout the O-MDA reaction due to the different on the deactivation of Mo species and the deactivation of Brӧnsted acid sites. Only when the deactivation of Mo/HZSM-5 is not significant during the reaction, the actual benzene selectivity can be estimated from the slope between benzene formation rate and methane consumption rate. it is estimated that approximately 60–80% of the methane consumed in O-MDA reaction is used to produce benzene during the first 5 reaction regenerations. The regenerable behavior of Mo/HZSM-5 enables the catalyst to have higher yields of aromatics. As shown in Fig. 5d, the cumulative amount of benzene produced by O-MDA reaction regeneration cycles is 16.3 mol/gcat, which is 2.44 times to that of single-pass aromatics (6.67 mol/gcat) and 5.80 times of that in the MDA reaction (2.81 mol/gcat). 3.3 Characterization of Mo/H-ZSM-5 catalysts before and after O-MDA reaction 3.3.1 XRD patterns of HZSM-5 and oxide Mo/HZSM-5 catalysts Fig. 6a shows the XRD patterns of HZSM-5 and oxide Mo/HZSM-5 catalysts. Where Mo/ HZSM-5 (0−1) is the fresh Mo/ HZSM-5 catalyst and Mo/HZSM-5 (0−2)-Mo/HZSM-5 (0−5) is the regenerated oxide Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst for the second, third, fourth, and fifth MDA reaction runs. For HZSM-5 zeolite, the diffraction peaks at 2θ= 7.8°, 8.7°, 22.9°, 23.2°, 23.6°, 23.8° and 24.3° correspond to (011), (200), (051), (−501/501), (−511/511), (033) and (−313/313) lattice planes, consistent with literature reports [26,32,44]. Almost all the diffraction peaks in the range of 2θ= 5°− 50° on oxide Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst is consistent with characteristic diffraction peaks of HZSM-5. Fig. 6b compares the XRD patterns of HZSM-5 and oxide Mo/HZSM-5 catalysts at 2θ = 25–30° to confirm the presence of peaks associated with Mo species. Despite the interference of HZSM-5, the peaks at 2θ = 27.3° of fresh and regenerated Mo/HZSM-5 are still significantly higher than those of HZSM-5, which should be attributed to the contribution from (021) plane of MoO3 crystals [45] . The peak width at half-height of XRD peak at 27.3° for HZSM-5 and regenerated Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst decreased as follows: Mo/HZSM-5(O-1) (0.2422°) > Mo/HZSM-5(O-2) (0.2376°) > Mo/HZSM-5(O-3) (0.2168°) > Mo/HZSM-5(O-4) (0.2090°) > Mo/HZSM-5(O-5) (0.1843°). According to the based on the Scherrer equation of D = k λ β cos θ （while k is equal to 0.89, λ is equal to 0.154 nm and β is the peak width at half height (FWHM)），the average diameter of MoO3 crystals increased in the order: Mo/HZSM-5(O-1) (33.3 nm) > Mo/HZSM-5(O-2) (34.0 nm) > Mo/HZSM-5(O-3) (37.2 nm) > Mo/HZSM-5(O-4) (38.7 nm) > Mo/HZSM-5(O-5) (43.8 nm). Results show that the crystal size of MoO3 on Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst increases as the cycles of MDA reaction regeneration are increased. Fig. 6c shows the relative intensities of the diffraction peaks at 2θ= 7.8°and 2θ= 22.9°for HZSM-5 and oxide Mo/HZSM-5 catalysts. The intensity of XRD diffraction peaks for Mo/HZS-5 catalysts decreased gradually with the increase of regeneration reaction cycle times, and the decreasing trend was as follows: HZSM-5 > > Mo/HZSM-5(O-1) > Mo/HZSM-5(O-2) >Mo/HZSM-5(O-3) > Mo/HZSM-5(O-4) > Mo/HZSM-5(O-5). The decrease on diffraction peak intensity on XRD patterns of Mo/HZSM-5 indicates that the decreased on the crystallinity of zeolite framework. Compared with the fresh Mo/HZSM-5（O-1）catalyst (relative intensity = 1.0), the peak intensity of Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst decreased by about 10–30% after one regeneration cycle. Within a few reaction-regeneration cycles, the relative peak intensity of the regenerated Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst tended to be stable. 3.3.2 Textural properties of Mo/HZSM-5 catalysts before and after regeneration Fig. 7a shows the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distributions of the fresh and regenerated oxide Mo/HZSM-5 catalysts. The quantity of adsorbed N2 increases rapidly with the increase of relative pressure in the range of relative pressure (P/P0) less than 0.05, indicating the existence of micropores in all the catalysts. The typical type IV adsorption-desorption isotherms were observed in the range of relative pressure (P/P0) from 0.05 to 0.95, indicating the formation of mesoporous channels in the samples [24,32]. Fig. 7b shows the pore size distribution of oxide Mo/HZSM-5 catalysts. With the increase of regeneration cycle time, the pore size distribution of the catalyst changed significantly in the range of 2 ∼ 6 nm. After the first reaction-regeneration process, the mesopores in the catalyst increased. After the catalyst was regenerated from the second to the fourth reaction cycles, the number of mesopores decreased. For the regenerated catalyst used for the fifth MDA reaction, the number of mesopores suddenly increased. Table 1 lists the specific surface area, pore volume, and average pore diameter of the Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst before and after O-MDA reaction. The decrease in the surface area and pore volume of catalyst was attributed to the coverage and accumulation of carbon deposits on the surface and pore structure of Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst during O-MDA reaction. The specific surface area of the fresh Mo/HZSM-5 (O-1) catalyst decreased by nearly 24% after reaction, while the specific surface area of the regenerated Mo/HZSM-5 (O-2) catalyst decreased by only 10%. After regeneration, the total specific surface area of both catalysts was nearly completely recovered. The micropore specific surface area and micropore volume of the catalyst did not decrease, indicating that the carbon deposition on Mo/HZSM-5 (O-1) and Mo/HZSM-5 (O-2) catalysts was mostly concentrated outside the micropores. In the third regeneration cycle, the specific surface area and micropore volume of the zeolite in the catalyst decreased, but the external specific surface area and pore volume of the catalyst did not decrease, indicating that the decrease in the specific surface area of the Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst may be caused by carbon deposition in micropores although oxygen-containing compounds were simultaneously added to the methane feed. After the third regeneration cycle, both total surface area and the external surface area of the catalyst significantly decreased, suggesting that some mesopores are blocked during reaction regeneration process. For the catalyst from the fourth to the fifth O-MDA reaction, the micropore specific surface area of Mo/HZSM-5 decreased significantly, while a large number of 2–6 nm mesopores were formed. Meanwhile, the total specific surface area, the external surface area and average pore diameter increased. The results showed that in the regeneration process, the elimination of carbon deposition and the recovery of carbonized molybdenum species may occur simultaneously in zeolite micropores. Repetitive reaction regeneration from the fifth O-MDA reaction can lead to the destruction and collapse of the zeolite framework, and the overlap of some fragments to form new mesopores. The collapse of the zeolite framework should be due to the induction of large-sized MoO3 aggregates near the framework Al [6,25,32]. 3.3.3 Raman characterization of Mo/HZSM-5 catalysts before and after regeneration Fig. 8a shows Raman spectrum of HZSM-5 and oxide Mo/HZSM-5 catalysts. The peak at 371 cm−1 in Raman spectrum can be attributed to the characteristic peak of the framework structure of HZSM-5, which is derived from the double pentacyclic vibration of zeolite [8]. The intensity of this peak is relative weak on Mo/HZSM-5 catalysts, which may be due to the presence of Mo-oxo species on the outer surface of the catalyst [46]. Compared with HZSM-5, the newly appeared characteristic peaks at 277 cm−1, 331 cm−1, 660 cm−1, 814 cm−1 and 984 cm−1 on oxide Mo/HZSM-5 catalysts are attributed to crystallites of α-MoO3 structure [8,47–49]. Briefly, the characteristic peak at 277 cm−1 corresponds to the characteristic peak of Mo-O-Mo deformation vibration. The characteristic peak at 331 cm−1 corresponds to the characteristic peak of MoO bending vibration. The characteristic peak at 660 cm−1 corresponds to the characteristic peak of Mo-O-Mo symmetric stretching vibration. The characteristic peak at 814 cm−1 corresponds to the characteristic peak of Mo-O-Mo antisymmetric stretching vibration. The characteristic peak at 984 cm−1 corresponds to the characteristic MoO stretching vibration peak [47]. No extra Raman peak appeared after multiple reaction regeneration cycles indicates that the coordination structure of Mo species on the outer surface of Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst is not significantly affected. The results suggest that after regeneration，the spreading of MoO3 crystallites starts to occur on H-ZSM5 surfaces to form (MoO3) n oligomers, while the size of the oligomers remains large enough to show intense peaks at 814 and 984 cm−1. The peak width at half-height of Raman peak at 814 cm−1 for the regenerated catalyst decreased as follows: Mo/HZSM-5(O-1)(28.81 cm−1) > Mo/HZSM-5(O-2)(26.09 cm−1)> Mo/HZSM-5(O-3)(25.81 cm−1)> Mo/HZSM-5(O-4)(24.68 cm−1)> Mo/HZSM-5(O-5)(23.21 cm−1), indicates that the size of MoO3 crystallites on surface of Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst increased continuously during the multiple reaction regeneration processes [8,47–49]. The ultra-high Raman peak intensity at 814 cm−1 on Mo/ZSM-5 (O-5) catalyst should originate from the collapse of the catalyst framework. BET results showed that 1/3 of the micropore surface area of Mo/ZSM-5 (O-4) catalyst was destroyed, and the external surface area was more than doubled, resulting in a significant increase in the amount of MoO3 crystals on the external surface of Mo/ZSM-5 (O-5) catalyst. The results indicate that multiple reaction regeneration processes will lead to the aggregation of Mo species on surface of the catalyst. Fig. 8b shows the Raman spectra of the used HZSM-5 catalyst, while Mo/HZSM-5(C-1)-Mo/HZSM-5(C-5) is the catalyst after first, second, third, fourth and fifth O-MDA reaction. It is generally accepted the deactivation of Mo/zeolite catalyst in MDA reaction was caused by severe carbon deposition. After O-MDA reaction, three characteristic peaks were found at 1170 cm−1, 1338 cm−1 and 1586 cm−1, and the characteristic peak of α-MoO3 disappears, which is attributed to the carbonization of oxide molybdenum species [50]. The weak peak at 1170 cm−1 is usually attributed to the D peak of amorphous, nanostructured, diamond-like carbon species with sp3 hybrid structures [50,51]. Ferrari further attributed the carbon species at 1150 cm−1 and 1480 cm−1 to trans-polyacetylene, which is reasonable to be produced in the MDA reaction [51]. With the progress of the reaction regeneration cycle, the polyacetylene-like carbon deposition gradually decreases until it disappears, which is due to the weakening of methane dissociation ability on Mo species. The decreasing of methane dissociation ability on Mo species may be due to the formation of larger MoCx species originated from the aggregated Mo species on surface of the catalyst. It has been reported that large MoCx particles are undesirable because the exhibit high selectivity toward coke and accelerating deactivation of the catalyst [52]. Hensen found that the loss of MoCx dispersion was the main reason for the decrease in methane conversion [8]. The spectral peak at 1338 cm−1 is considered to be the D peak formed by random mode scattering of graphite crystals, indicating the existence of disordered surface carbon on the surface of the used Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst [50,53]. The spectral peak at 1586 cm−1 is considered to be the G peak formed by stretching vibration of the sp2 hybrid orbital, indicating the existence of highly ordered graphitic carbon species on the surface of the catalyst, which is consistent with the literature reports [50,53]. 3.3.4 NH3-TPD characterization of HZSM-5 and oxide Mo/HZSM-5 catalysts The acidic properties of HZSM-5 and oxide Mo/HZSM-5 catalysts were detected by NH3-TPD technology (shown in Fig. S2). The NH3 desorption peak area corresponds to the amount of weak, medium, and strong acid sites on the Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst. Previous studies have shown that the low-temperature peak is associated with physisorbed NH3 and desorption of NH3 at weakly acidic sites of nonexchangeable cations. The medium temperature peak is associated with the desorption of NH3 adsorbed on exchangeable proton sites, The high temperature peak is associated with the adsorption of NH3 on the strong acid sites (Brӧnsted acid sites) of the acidic hydroxide Si-OH-Al [54] ( Table 2). After Mo is loaded on HZSM-5 zeolite, the NH3 desorption peak area of high temperature peak is significantly reduced by 85% compared with HZSM-5. Iglesia and co-workers found that MoOx species migrate to the ZSM-5 outer surface at about 623 K and migrate inside zeolite channels via surface and gas-phase transport at between 773 and 973 K. MoOx species exchange at the acidic site to form a cation (Mo2O5)2+ structures interact with exchange site, thus reducing the amount of Brӧnsted acid sites [39,55]. Compared with the fresh catalyst (Mo/HZSM-5(O-1), the weak, medium, and strong acid sites of the Mo/HZSM-5(O-2) catalyst can be almost recovered in the first reaction regeneration cycle. This should be the main reason for the recovery of O-MDA reaction performance of the regenerated catalyst. After further reaction and regeneration of the Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst, the strong acidity of the catalyst decreased to a relatively stable level, which was about half of that of the fresh Mo/HZSM-5 (O-1) catalyst. It this stage, the selectivity of benzene can be restored to the initial value. However, with the increase of regeneration times, the decreasing trend of benzene selectivity in the reaction process gradually increased. It can be seen from the XRD peak intensity that the crystallinity of the zeolite framework in Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst was relatively stable at this stage. From the slop between benzene formation rate and methane consumption rate as shown in Fig. 6c, more than 2/3 of methane molecule can be effectively converted into benzene. At this stage, the deactivation of Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst in O-MDA reaction should depend more on the decrease of the Mo species aggregation and the decline on the dissociation ability of large size Mo species than on the decrease of strong acid sites amount in aromatic formation. 3.4 O2-TG characterization of the used Mo/H-ZSM-5 catalysts Fig. 9a-c shows the TG, DTG and the deconvolution of DTG profiles of the used HZSM-5 catalyst. The combustion of coke on Mo/HZSM-5 catalysts occur mainly in the range of 723 K and 923 K as shown in Fig. 9b. As the reaction regeneration cycle progressed, the peak with combustion temperature at around 783 K became sharper, and the corresponding peak temperature shifted to lower temperatures. Fig. 9c shows the deconvolution of O2-DTG profiles. A low temperature peak at around 793 K and a high temperature peak at around 853 K can be found. The Low- and high-temperature coke deposition on Mo/HZSM-5 catalysts can be identified in two different ways. According to Kosinov’s study with dissolving zeolite template in HF, there is no significant chemical difference between MDA coke burning at low temperature and at high temperature. In their O2-TG/DTG analysis, the researchers speculated that MoO3 could be used as a catalyst to influence the combustion behavior of carbonaceous materials by acting as an efficient combustion catalyst. The apparent difference in TG/DTG profiles should be ascribed to the catalytic combustion of a certain fraction of carbon over MoO3 and the diffusion-limited combustion inside the pores. They propose that the MDA reaction involves activation of methane over atomically dispersed Mo centers, anchored to the zeolite framework, producing reactive radicals or primary coupled C2Hx fragments that react with polyaromatic hydrocarbon species confined in the pores of ZSM-5 zeolite and occupying at least 10–15% of the microporous space [36]. It is speculated that among the condensed aromatics that can be formed in the micropores of ZSM-5 zeolite, linear acenes are of particular interest, because they become increasingly unstable when more aromatic rings are added. Hydrogenolysis of acenes may take place, resulting in the formation of benzene and other light aromatics. The proposed "hydrocarbon pool mechanism" findings possess some similarity to the well-established methanol-to-hydrocarbons (MTH) mechanism. However, it is still controversial whether the methane aromatization reaction follows a "bifunctional reaction mechanism" or a "hydrocarbon pool mechanism" [56,57]. Previous studies have shown that the MDA reaction may simultaneously follow different reaction mechanisms. Nikolay and Hensen mentioned that the complete mechanism of the MDA reaction remains unclear [6]. For example, the possibility of both bifunctional and hydrocarbon pool-like mechanisms to co-exist during the MDA reaction cannot yet be ruled out. If there is still a bifunctional reaction mechanism for the MDA reaction, it suggests that the coke deposition on the outer surface of the catalyst may be different from the coke deposition in the internal pores of the zeolite. A study by Liu found that the peak intensities of high temperature and low temperature carbon deposition on Mo/HZSM-5 catalysts decreased after treatment with TP-H2 and TP-CO2; however, high temperature carbon deposition was far more affected [34,58]. However, if diffusion limitation is causing a difference between a high temperature peak and a low temperature peak, then the reduction in low peak temperature should be more pronounced after H2 treatment for the same type of carbon deposition. Therefore, it suggested coke deposition burned on low temperature and high temperature might be difference. According to the reports, graphitic carbon deposition dominates the carbonaceous material corresponding to the low temperature peak [33,37,58]. The carbonaceous material corresponding to the high temperature peak consists of oligomeric PAH hydrocarbons, which are located mainly in zeolite pores [35,58]. It turns out that the TPO measurement is an effective method that can analyze the molar number and type of coke based on the amount of CO and CO2 after the burning of carbon deposition [18,30,33,58]. Similar to TPO, O2-TG measurement can also determine the amount and type of carbon deposition based on the mass deviation of carbon deposition combustion. In previous reports, it was found that the amount carbon deposition burning at different temperature could be well calculated by deconvolution [18]. As can be seen from the O2-TG deconvolution results in Table 3, the total carbon deposition of O-MDA reaction on the fresh Mo/HZSM-5(O-1) catalyst after 6 h of reaction is 22.4 mg/gcat, of which the carbon deposition of high temperature peak is about 9.0 mg/gcat, which is about 15–25% of the total carbon deposition of completely deactivated Mo/HZSM-5 in a similar MDA reaction. The amount of low and high temperature carbon deposited on the regenerated Mo/HZSM-5 (O-2) catalyst was lower than that on the fresh Mo/HZSM-5 (O-1) catalyst after 6 h of O-MDA reaction, which may be the main reason for the smaller decrease in the specific surface area of the catalyst. The dissociation ability (methane conversion varies with TOS) of the fresh Mo/HZSM-5 (O-1) catalyst may be slightly higher than that of the first-regenerated Mo/HZSM-5 (O-2) catalyst, which may lead to a slight decrease in low temperature carbon deposits on the Mo/HZSM-5 (O-2) catalyst. The formation of low temperature carbon deposits is closely related to the dissociation of methane on outer surface of the catalyst. XRD and Raman results indicate that, as the proceed of O-MDA reaction regeneration cycles, the size of the surface MoO3 crystals grows larger. During the regeneration process, some isolated MoO3 (the melting point of MoO3 is 1068 K) with large size will be difficult to redisperse [59,60]. More carbon deposits tend to be dispersed in the micropores of the zeolite. Refractory isolate MoO3 species in the zeolite pores after regeneration will more easily lead to the formation of Al2(MoO4)3 by dealumination and structural destruction of the zeolite framework [25]. 3.5 Deactivation behavior of Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst during MDA reaction-regeneration cycles Fig. 10 shows 27Al MAS NMR spectra of the fresh Mo/HZSM-5（O-1）catalyst and regenerated Mo/HZSM-5（O-8）catalyst. The resonance absorption peak at δ = 0 ppm is attributed to the octahedrally coordinated non-framework aluminum species. The resonance absorption peak at δ = 54 ppm is attributed to the aluminum atom species of the HZSM-5 framework, which exists in the form of tetrahedral coordination [32]. The resonance absorption peak at δ = −12 ppm is attributed to octahedral aluminum in crystalline Al2(MoO4)3, which is related to the induction of the Mo species [25]. It was found the resonance absorption peak at δ = 54 ppm decreased in the order Mo/HZSM-5 (O-1) ≈ Mo/HZSM-5 (O-3) > Mo/HZSM-5 (O-5) > > Mo/HZSM-5 (O-8). Results showed that the zeolite framework did not collapse significantly during the first three regeneration cycles. When comparing the NMR results of Mo/HZSM-5(O-5) and Mo/HZSM-5(O-8) catalyst, a sharp reduction in the 27Al NMR peak (δ = 54 ppm) associated with the HZSM-5 framework and an increase in the 27Al NMR peak (δ = −12 ppm) associated with aluminum molybdate were found by continuously MDA reaction regeneration process. Combining the changes in MDA reaction performance with reaction regeneration cycles as shown in Fig. 5a, it is proposed that the actual collapse of zeolite framework should occur from the fifth regeneration, which was also supported by BET results. In O-MDA reaction regeneration processes, the increase of C2 selectivity and the decrease of benzene selectivity with TOS (shown in Fig. 5a) was strengthen with the proceed of reaction regeneration processes, which should be due to the gradually destroy of zeolite framework and the decrease on acidity of Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst. Before zeolite framework was severely collapsed, the peak intensity of Mo/HZSM-5 and amount of strong Brönsted acid site is relative stable. After the collapse of zeolite framework, the amount of strong acid sites will drop significantly, which makes it difficult to effectively convert the CxHy formed by methane dissociation and decreases the aromatics selectivity in the products rapidly. From sixth to eighth reaction regeneration cycles, C2 even replaces the aromatics as the main product in O-MDA reaction. As shown from TEM images in Fig. 11, a small number of clusters were found on Mo/HZSM-5(O-1) catalyst, whereas much more clusters were observed in the Mo/HZSM-5(O-5) catalyst. The cluster lattice spacing is 0.3937 nm on Mo/HZSM-5(O-1) and is 0.3968 nm on Mo/HZSM-5(O-5) catalyst, which can be identified as (100) planes of MoO3 crystal [61]. As shown by the TEM statistics, MoO3 particles in Mo/HZSM-5 (O-1) catalysts are smaller than those in Mo/HZSM-5 (O-5), which is consistent with XRD results. XRD, Raman and TEM results indicates that as the reaction regeneration proceeds, more MoO3 clusters aggregate on the catalyst surface, and the size of the clusters increases. It is argued that due to the formation of more and larger mesopores, more isolated large-sized MoO3 crystals were formed on surface of the catalyst. Isolated MoO3 species within micropores may induce framework Al to form aluminum molybdate, which caused irreversible damage to the zeolite framework [26,28,29,39]. 27Al NMR results of the regenerated catalyst after the eighth reaction confirmed that the structural damage of zeolite was caused by the formation of aluminum molybdate due to the removal of framework aluminum. From the fifth to eight reaction regeneration cycle, the initial methane conversion rate did not decrease significantly, while the aromatics selectivity decreased significantly. Before the framework of zeolite was collapsed, the amount of strong Bronsted acid site is relative stable. Due to the collapse of zeolite framework, the amount of strong acid sites will drop significantly, which makes it difficult to effectively convert the CxHy formed by methane dissociation and decreases the aromatics selectivity in the products rapidly. It can be seen from Fig. 4 that in the 6–8 reaction regeneration cycle, C2 even replaces the aromatics as the main product at the final stage of MDA reaction. The growth of Mo crystals and the corresponding framework dealumination during O-MDA reaction regeneration cycles are two main reasons for the deactivation of Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst. During the oxygen calcination process, the maintenance of strong acid sites in zeolite is the key to the recovery of catalyst activity after regeneration. During the reaction regeneration process, the size of Mo species becomes larger, and more carbon deposition tends to distribute in the micropores of the catalyst. The collapse and destruction of the catalyst structure increases as the attraction of more isolated large-sized Mo species to the framework alumina increases. This makes catalyst deactivation and reduction of aromatics yield irreversible in O-MDA reaction. 4 Conclusion The reaction regeneration cycle of the O-MDA reaction was investigated by adding an oxygen-containing gas component to extend the effective reaction time. The cumulative of aromatics amount produced by O-MDA reaction regeneration cycles is 16.3 mol/gcat, which is 2.44 times to that in a single-pass O-MDA reaction (6.67 mol/gcat) and 5.80 times to that in MDA reaction (2.81 mol/gcat). Addition of oxygen-containing components can effectively extend the reaction time per pass but cannot prevent the deactivation of catalyst during regeneration. MoO3 species, acidity, and texture properties of the Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst was almost identical after the first regeneration, which may account for the complete recovery of methane conversion and aromatic formation. Molar ratio of ethylene/benzene in the product was almost the same with TOS during O-MDA reaction. Before the zeolite framework collapses, the crystallinity of the zeolite framework gradually decreases, and the number of strong acid sites decreases to a stable level. The increase in MoO3 size on outer surface of catalyst leads to the formation of more disordered graphitic carbon deposits under the same reaction conditions. Methane dissociation ability is significantly reduced, while the initial aromatics selectivity can be fully recovered. When severe collapse of the zeolite framework occurs, the generation of mesopores due to the reduction of micropores in Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst leads to the formation of more Mo species with larger size. The formed large-sized Mo species may accelerate the collapse of zeolite framework, resulting the formation of aluminum molybdate. This irreversibly destroys the Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst structure with increasing reaction regeneration cycles. Currently, the conversion of methane decreases slowly, but the selectivity of aromatics decreases rapidly. coredata.dc:description: Reaction regeneration cycle of methane dehydroaromatization (MDA) with oxygen-containing gas components was studied. XRD, BET, Raman, NH3-TPD, O2-TG/DTG, TEM and 27Al-NMR were used to monitor textural structure, Mo species, and acid sites of catalyst before and after regeneration. Addition of oxygen components can extend reaction time per pass but cannot prevent the deactivation of regenerated catalyst. MoO3 species, acidity, and texture properties of Mo/HZSM-5 was identical after first regeneration, which may account for complete recovery of methane conversion and aromatic formation. During regeneration, the inevitable increase in Mo species size disrupts carbon deposition and significantly reduces methane dissociation. The crystallinity and number of strong acid sites of Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst decreased to a stable level before the collapse of zeolite framework without hindering aromatic formation. The recovered large-sized Mo species may accelerate the collapse of zeolite framework, irreversibly destroying Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Reaction regeneration cycle of Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst in methane dehydroaromatization with the addition of oxygen-containing components
